are by no means in healthy state In order 10 see the full effects of the habits above ailn- ded to, 1t is necessary to look at cases in

 winch they have been carried to an excessive degree. In npopuious towns there are oppor- tunitles of observing these effects on an extcn- siVe scale. The labouring classes, who are in general firm, robust men from the country. consume enormous quantities of beer, porter, and spirits, besides double the quantity of animal food the health requires. It is among these people that we see attacks of inAamatory disorders of the most violent kind. Such injuries which in others would be unimpOrtant, produce in them severe in hamation, the nature of which is always Obsti- nate and in it's termination frequently fatal. They live in fact on the brink of disease the slightest accident often carries them off, and if they escape casualties, their habits of living lead to a variety of diseases and premature dissolution; the majority not surviving the age of fifty.-Med. Hut.

BY S. S. SMITH, EDITOR AND PROPRIETOR.

ANOTHER LETTER FROM DIR. HOWE. NAPoLI DI ROMAN, Sept. 12, 1926. Dear Sir; Since the date of my last, (Aug. 16) affairs have remained in nearly the same state as then described them to you, with this difference, however, that every day that the enemy is delayed from important operations, is day gained by the Greeks for it brings us nearer the rainy season, when they must necessarily give up, in great measure, hostile pro- ceedings.

 Athens has been closly invested for some time by the Albanians, under Reshed Pa- sha. In fact, he has possession of the lower town: for, the Greeks, finding it al- mostimpossible to defend the extensive cir cult of the walls, abandoned them and re- tired into the Acropolis, and body of Turks entered the place. On the 18th August,i it was resolved that an attack should be made upon them by the Greeks, who were without the town. Accordingly the Regulars, under Col. Fabvier, amounting 1 to about fifteen hundred men, and the Ir- regulars, under Canascakis, to three thou sand fell upon them, and drove them back some miles from the town, and cut them

 

 place. In this affair, the corps of Phil hellenians, composed of about 15O Euro peans, behaved in such manner as to force the admiration of Turks and Greeks. The next day, the enimy advanced again, and on the 2Oth they were again attacked and driven back. The affair lasted all day, and at dark it was arranged that the irreg- ulars should continue the pursuit, while the tactics Irregular troops] should remain in some gardens, a few miles from Athens as a Corps de rCserve. But what was the as- tonishment of Fabvier and his men, two hours after dark, when they thought the Greeks to be far in advance, to find the Turks, in vast numbers, rushing into the garden, sabre in hand, with their horrible cry of Allah-hu, and cutting bown all who opposed them. Confusion immediately succeeded.-Abattis, commander of the first battalion, either from weakness or misunderstanding, disobeyed his orders. and all retired rapidly to neighboring hill, from whence they endeavored with their four field pieces. to check the ene- my. Two of them breaking down they were obliged to leave them in the hands of the enemy, and continued their retreat to the shore opposite Salamis, where, after burying their cannon, they embarked, and crossed over to the Island, having lost a. bout 80 mon. Fabvier accused Canasca- kis of having betrayed him, but it will prob- ably turn out misunderstanding and, so far from being discouraged, the Greeks are prepairing to unite again and attack the en- imy. As for the Acropolis, the Turks cannot take it by assault: as for famine the garrison have provision for two years. Bombardment has been tried in vain, so that there remains no other way but that of mining This fear, in some measure 1; for, from tho almost perpendicular rising of the rock, on which the fortress is built, an enemy, who has possession of the town, may commence his operations almost under the feet of the besiegers; However, it would be exhibiting degree of skill and enter prise which have rarely shown in Turkish Armies,to attempt so tedious process.

 Ibrahim Pasha, greatly weakened and in want of endorsements, can undertake no operation more important than that ol burning villages, until the arrival of the Egyptian fleet, and this, it appears, ixde-

A Tale, founded on fact, and translated from

 the Spanish of the Rev. Joseph Blanco

 White.

 triau service, took me with him, when only six years old, to Malines. The Archbishop of that city, the Count of F-, seeing me there at different times, took fancy to me, and offered to send me to Vienna, to be edu- cated in the house of his sister, the'C Countess of S--. until there should be vacancy

of silent love, which never would have bro ken from the secrecy of the heart to which it was confined, but for the evil fortune which cherished my fancy for a while with the de- ceitful delights of hope, in order to give d sharper edge to the suficrings that awaited both myself and the innocent object of my passion. While l resided with the two sis ters, the youthful gaiety and merriment with which they treated me, made me sort of voluntary slave to them both. One day when theIr father came to see us, he found me at 1 short distance from the house, drawing map 0t the surrounding country, from which af forwards formed the model now before you. was seated upon the grass beneath tree, but without my shoes upon my feet. "How IS this, my friend ," said he, ''are you so ecO- nomlcal as to wear your shoes only in the city 7" No sir" replied. ''my shoes are Tn your daug ghters' possession: for they lay an embargo on them whenever they wish to prevent my leaving the place." Upon hear ing this, the good man was ready to die with laughter; then, wishing to ascertain the na- ture of the employment in which he found me engaged, he began to examne the map. Such however was his ignorance, that he was ut terly incapable of comprehending the mean ing ot 1t. At length, after many efforts, Isuc- ceeded in making him perceive in it his own house, with the lake, the mountains, and the woods. He was perfectly astonished, and al most took me for magician.

 The situation in which now found my self, though delightful beyond measure, could ] not, was aware, continue much longer with 1 out producing crisis that must make me ei- ther happy or miserable for the remainder of my life.

 The time at length arrived when it became absolutely necessary for me to take my de- parture, and without having made, even indi- rectly, the slightest intmation of my passion to her who was the object of it. Overwhel- med in the melancholy of my thoughts, lost all my former animation and gaiety of spirits, which were succeeded by q dejection that in creased every hour. Instead of proposing as usual to accompany tho sisters in their walks and diversions, would retire. almost uncon- scious of what was doing, to the shade of tree, with some paper and pencil, as if for the purpose of drawing. There would sit for hours, and find at last that had not drawn line.

 One morning when wrapped up in one of these melancholy moods suddenly pcrcei- ved the two sisters. approaching slowly thro' the wood in which they found me. They advanced at a little distance from each other the younger appearing to lead the way; the object of my passion cast d look towards me, and then with blush retired behind her sis ter. But the younger, with countenance full ofl life and animation, opposed her retreat and taking her again by the hand, pulled her towards me speaking to her at the same time a few words, which l could not hear, in a tone of attectionate anger. She came up to l me at last, and with her accustomed iveliness said to me, You must tell us the cause of your melancholy, or we will instantly deprive you of the honor Ofbeng our knight-errant." Forcing a smile to my lip, endeavored to answer her in the same lively tone, but my ] tongue failed to execute nay wish: could only utter complaint against my ill-fortune in being under the necessity of taking my de- parture in few days. "Then you think of leaving us," continued the younger sister, Heaven knows," replied, "how deeply the thought of being obliged to do so affects me-" "And do you grieve for both of us C. quaIly?" The blush which instantly covered the face and neck of my beloved, blinded me at once to every other consideration, and, seizing her hand with transport. pressed it to nay lips-then dropped it moment to clasp within both of mine that of my kind medria tix. "Very well, sir" she replied, in a tone of affected gravity: !" l see plainly how little you care for me. Nevertheless, as I am of generous temper, and feel no desire for re- venge, shall now inform thee, most sorrow full knight, that have put the question for thee to my sister, and that thou hast only to get the rank of captain forthwith, in order to be sure of obtaining the incOmparable happi- ness and exalted honour, &c. Sc. of being her husband.-Bless the man he stands as if he had been turned into statuc."

 l Such indeedI renamed fora few moments: then in a transport exclaimed, " Is it possible? Surely you are deceiying me. .'-"No, no,my friend, she does not deceive you," replied my beloved: and throwing her arms around her sisters neck, bathed her cheek with grateful tears.

 Happy! thrice happy am l." exclaim- ed: the rank which you have made the condi- ton of our marriage,will be obtained in a few days. We shall part, therefore. since my pro- fessional duty requires it; but soon shall you behold me here again, to claim the promised hand of her whom adore"

 (To be concluded in our nert.)

 Free Living.-One of the most common causes of all violent disorders, is that which is popularly termed fullness of the vessels, or technically, plethoric condition of the sys- tenn, arising from errors in diet; from excess or imprudent indulgence in the quality or

Vienna, where was brought up with the ne- phew of the Archbishop; who, together with his relations, all persons of great influence, | showed me the strongest marks of affection, and promoted to the utmost my education at the academy.

 At the time when held only the rank of a lieutenant, l was selected by the government ! for the purpose of making some trigOnOmetri- cal surveys in Hungary. l set out according ly, with an escort of soldiers appointed for the management of the mathematical instruments. On the road l found myself treated like a prince by all the post masters, who, at the very sound of the name of an officer cOmmis- stoned by the court. will almost lick the ground to serve him. NOrecOmmendatiOn,h however, of this kind is required to induce the upper classes to give an officer frank and hospita- ble reception. The hospitality, indeed, which | reigns through Hungary, together with the primitive simplicity and purity of manners, which at the period speak of prevailed a. mong the females of the country, will very plainly appearin the course of my narrative. Being young, soldier, and employed by the government, could scarcely fail of hay ing much attention paid to me at Presburg.- had not been long there before the season of Carnival came on: during which the no- bles are in the habit of giving public balls.- The customs of the country on this occasion are singular. Should there be garrison, or any officers in the city, they immediately re- ceive tickets of admission to the balls, without being at any trouble to procure them. The directors make a list of all who are invited ;- and if the number of men should be found to exceed that of females, they propose the names of some young ladies of their acquan- tance, which are inserted in the list to make up the deficiency. When this is done, it would be considered improper in the parents ofthe young ladies to prevent their daughters from attending the balls.

 "As soon as they commenced, I became acquainted with two sisters, the ladies of P-, young women of great beauty and agreeable manners: the elder excelled in the waltz, the younger loved the country dance. was charmed with them both but soon from day to day. Yet why should I cherish or make known passion which could not terminate happily? What folly, for a young

 lieutenant without fortune, to think of offering his hand to young female, born :o higher and better hopes On the last day, however, of our meeting, l could do no less, as l had no acquaintance with the family of my partner, than take my leave. by saying to her, We have now danced the keruhW tor concusion) and in truth here my story ends, for shall never see you again." "Not so,'' she repli- ed, with an openness of manner quite idnes- cribable," unless indeed you wish to run away from us. Every thing is arranged for your visiting in our family. My father knows who you are; and |, too, am more interested in the matter than, perhaps, you imagine.- Come, therefore, if you please, and visit us to- morrow" Such innocence and simplicity won possession in moment of my whole heart; though to say the truth, the whole of it had been made captive long before. re- solved, however, at the same time most firm Iy not to abuse in the slightest degree the O. penness and simplicity of the fair object of my love.

 Hitherto my residence had been in the I'm perial Castle; which, as it commands, both in a geographical and military se:se, the city and the Danube, affords to the eye one of the Ioveliest prospects to be met with in Hungary. From the moment, however, in which l re- ccived the invitation l have mentioned, till that of my departure with a beating heart to pay the expected visit, Presburg and the Danube with all their beauties, had vanished | from my eyes. Scarcely upon my arrival at their fathers, had entered the house, when the two sisters, placing themselves one on each side of me, took me by the hand to in troduce me to him. In spite of the agitation ofmy mind, could scarcely forbear smiling when the good knight received me as if he had been bishop pronouncing blessing over me.

 Uprl my asking the reason of so unusual a ceremony, l immediately perceived by the answer given to me, the state of ignorance and superstition in which the country was sunk; for the object in making the sign of the cross over me was, they said, to prevent my entrance into their house from being attended with any iIl-fortune. Would that such a precaution could have been efectual! or that, in the room of superstitious ceremony, l could have offered prayer to Heaven capa- ble of averting the misfortunes which l was the innocent means of bringing upon the fam fly who had so hospitably received me under their roof.

 Ihad continued for some time 10 visit them with the freedom of "a near relation, when one day their father said to me, My friend, have favour to ask of you. My wife is so unwel that am prevented from going to my estate in the country, as had at first intend ed. But, as my daughters know how to man. age my affairs there as well as myself, 1 think of sending them thither in my place, and should be greatly obliged to you, if you would accompany them." Such a request | f oc c%I

A Coop HIT.-ScasOnGbL for Con- greSS.-Mr. Sergeant POpham, when Speaker of the House of Commons, which had sat long and done nothing, coming one day to Queen Elizabeth, she said to him, Now MT. Speaker, what has pas 1 sed'in the House?" He answered, "May it please your Majesty-eIcUem weeks F''- FIREs.-The extensive Iron Works at Carthage, N. Y. where destroyed by fire on the night of 22d ut. They were in- sured.-On the 30th ut. three story wooden house, corner of Prince and Cros- by streets, New ork, was mostly con- sumed. The Presbyterian Church in Murray street narrowly escaped confa- grafton on the following evening, fire hav- ing communicated from one of the fues used to warm it.-A fire broke out in Northampton, in a room occupied by MT. Colton, as Looking-glass factory; it was extinguished with little damage.

 A certain doctor Fitch gives in the Ga zette, paper published at Le Roy, Gen. nessee County, N. Y. that he will take produce in payment for his physic,i if deliv- cred at his barn by the 10th inst; and from those who are poor and cannot pay mon- ey or produce, he will take Brush fence or Buck Vheat Straw, if they will only bring it by that time.

 GEORGIA LEG1sLATURE.-A bill has passed the House of Represetatives, ap- propriating 10000 dollars for the purpose of clearing and deepning the River Savan- nah, between Augusta and Savannah.- The work is to be executed under the superintendence of four commissioners, and in conjunction with the state of South Carolina, as proposed by that State on previous occasions.

1UHtOGt0IUtOfC uN LlACCHCOIS Dl,UU Commissioner S1,25 The following beautiful lines of original po- ctry were written in young ladies Album & thence transcribed for this paper.1 HOW COLD ARE THESE SKIES! How cold are these skies Hoary winter re-

 ciined

 On his snow drifts, the charms of earth's be-

 som defOrms And the fields and the groves and the heavens

 are signed To the rule and the wrath of the spirits of

 storms.

 Yet these cold skies the earth have drest| In saint-like vesture, white and warm; And spread mantle OCT her breast, To shield it from the freezing storm. So not the coldest blast, that flies Ger hOpe's young flowers, the heart shall

 chill,

 If in the storm, it Iowiy lies And waits the AlI-ruling Spirits will.

 J.P. I4itchheld, Jan. II, 1897. The following lines were written by the Hon. Henry St. George Tucker, of Virginia, on being requested to know why he had ceas- ed to court the poetic muse. Days of my youth, ye have gIided away, Hairs of my youth, ye are frosted and gray, Eyes ofmy youth, your keen sight is no more. Checks of my youth, ye are furrow'd all Der, Strength of my youth. all your vgour is gone, Thoughts of my youth, your gay visions are

 flown.

 Days Of my youth, wish not your recall, Hairs of my youth, I'm content ye should fall, Eyes of my youth, ye much evil have seen, Cheeks of my youth, bath < in tears ye have

 been,

 Thoughts of my youth, ye have led me astray, Strength of my youth why lament your de-

 cay.

 Days of my age. ye will shortly he past, Pains of my age, yet awhile ye can last, Joys ofmy age, in true wisdom delight, Eyes of my age, be Religion your light, Thoughts of my age, dread ye not the cold

 sod,

 Hopes of my age be ye fix'd on your God. These beautiful lines are from the Memori- dl. published in Boston by True and Green "Cornelia," Mrs. Hale, is called by some of the Buston papers, "and not inaptly' (says the Atbion) the Mrs. Hemans of America.

 THE LIGHT OF HOME.

 

 And thy spirit will sigh to roam, And thou must go ;-but never when there, Forget the light of home. Though pleasure may smile with ray more

 bright,

 It dazzles to lead astray; Like the meteor's flash twill deepen the night, When thou treadest thy lo:.ely way. But the hearth of home has constant flame, And pure as vestal fire; Twill burn, twill burn forever the same, For nature feeds the pyre. The sea of ambition is tempcst-tost, And thy hopes may vanish like foam But when sa,s are shiver'd and rudder lost Then look to the light of home. And there like star through the midnight

 cloud

 Thou shalt see the beacon bright, For never, till shining on thy shroud, Can be quenched its holy light. The sun of fame, aye twill gid the name, But the heart ne'er felt its ray; And fashions smiles that rich ones claim, Are but beams of wintry day. And how cold and how dim those beams

 would be,

 Should life's wretched wanderer come And my hoy. when the world is dark to thee. Then turn to the light of home.

 CORNELIA.

 A YEAR IN HUNGARY. A Tale, founded on fact, and translated from the Spanish of the Rev. Joseph Blanco White.

 "My father, who was Major in the Aus trian service, took me with him, when only six years old, to Malines. The Archbishop of that city, the Count of -, seeing me there at different times, took fancy to me, and offered to send me to Vienna, to be edu-

THE MEMORY OF FRIENDSHIP. Amid the deepest shades of gloom,

 That brood OCT life's decline, A vision rises from the tomb

 Lost friendship it is thine !- Thou comest like pilgrim grey. But light is round thy misty way,

 The light of early love When life was fresh and hope was high, And rainbows spahn'd the cloudless sky, And music filled the grove. 1t was joyous season. Mirth

 Fill'd up the laughing hours o then we never thought that earth

 Could nourish aught but flowers ARd oft when, in the still profound, We gaz'd upon the mountains round,

 Or trod the valley green Or mingled in the giddy rout, Till the far rocks sent back the shout,

 We deem that life had been, From ages past, a fairy dream

 OfunalIoy'd delight Der which young joys meridian beam

 Each day threw rays more bright. 1t was the summers calm-the bloom That clothes the flowers ere tempests come; The pause-when far and still, The cradled storm is lulPd to rest, And on the verdant valleys breast

 The dews their balm distil Once-'twas day as beautiful

 As ever knew the eastern cline, When flowers invited maids to cuI

 Them in their glorious prime l cast long ing, lingering look On the still vale and winding brook,

 And saw the laughing band Of merry school-mates gathering To the accustom'd sportive ring

 All sniling-hand in hand. My heart was light even then-I left

 My boyhOod's pleasant dome Nor knew till far, of friends bereft,

 How dear is home-sweet home But it was pleasant still, in dreams, To visit my own native streams-

 To join the good and gay To think how from the worlds rude blast should escape, and fly at last

 To home--to frienGs---for aye, Life had its troubles-I was worn

 With pain aud toll and care; MislOrtunes came-hut they were borne, And hope repelld dspar- At length the chain was broken-and sought once more my native land--

 My own sweet valley rangd- Its meads and brooks were still the same Twas to my home-my home-I came,

 But oh that home had chang'd! That gladsome band was scatter'd-gone-

 Over the worlds wide waste trimm'd our household fire alone, #

 The church yard had the rest stood upon the school-house green The place deserted long had been

 And, as weary pilgrim wends, He knows not whither-day by day, rov'd a-down life's dreary way,

 My all the memory of friends. -I D.
From the Trenton Emporium. THE MEMORY OF FRIENDSHIP.

!Sheridan's Greek.-Lord Be!grave having clenched a speech in the House of Commons with Greek quotation, Sheridan, in reply, admitted the force of the quotation as far as it went, "but'' said he "had the Noble Lord proceeded little farther, and completed the passage, he would have seen that it applied the other way" Sheridan then spouted something, ore rOtundo, which had all the ais, ous, kon, and kous, that give the world assu- rance of Greek quotation; upon which Lord BeIgrave very promptly and handsome ly compimented the Hon. Member on his readiness of recollection, and frankly admit ted that the continuation of the passage had the tendency ascribed to it by Sheridan, and that he had overlooked it at the moment when he gave his quotation. On the break ing up of the House, Fox, piqued himself on having some Greek, went up to Sheridan and asked him, Sheridan, how came you to be so ready with. that passage it certainly is as you say, but was not aware of it before you quoted it." It is unnecessary to observe, that there was no Greek Gt QU in Sheridan's inn promptu!

 Panthers killed.-A Monticello, N. Y. date of 29th Dec. says:

 "TwO Partners, one measuring nine feet from the nose to the tip of the tail, the other smaller. were killed a short time since in the town of Bethel, about seven miles from this village, by MT. Nelson Crocker. They were two out of drove of nine, probably emigrating from our woods to a warmer eli mate. One of the remaining seven was bad ly wounded, but not so much so as to be ta- ken. Our hunters have pursued them, and will give good account of them.

The following lines were written by the Hon. Henry St. George Tucker, of Virginia, on being requested to know why he had ceas- ed to court the poetic muse. Days of my youth, ye have gIided away, Hairs of my youth, ye are frosted and gray, Eyes ofmy youth, your keen sight is no more, Checks of my youth, ye are furrow'd all OCT, Strength of my youth. all your vgour is gone, Thoughts of my youth, your gay visions are

 flown.

Free Living.-One of the most common causes of all violent disorders, is that which is popularly termed fullness of the vessels, or technically, plethoric condition of the sys- tenn, arising from errors in diet; from excess or imprudent indulgence in the quality or quantity of food and drink The indulgences produce and keep up an unnatural excitement,

 under whick accidental circumstances now

 readily occasion disease of an acute and infia-

 matory character. They also affect the or gans of digestion, which arc possessed of all

 most unive ersal sympathy, and by furnishing an excessive quantity of new supplies, over load the vascular system, bringing it into a

 state in which local disease may be very easi-

 ly produced; and instead of furnishing healthy

 nourishment, convey the seeds of disease over the whole body. Individuals are not aware of the tendency of the habits in which they daily indulge, until disease manifests itself in 1 various parts of the body. In the first instance too pIethoric condition is eVinced by in crease is bulk, and Aorid, or rather healthy appearance but if we investigate the matter l more closely. we shall find that such persons

full articles.article:
are by no means in healthy state In order 10 see the full effects of the habits above ailn- ded to, 1t is necessary to look at cases in

 winch they have been carried to an excessive degree. In npopuious towns there are oppor- tunitles of observing these effects on an extcn- siVe scale. The labouring classes, who are in general firm, robust men from the country. consume enormous quantities of beer, porter, and spirits, besides double the quantity of animal food the health requires. It is among these people that we see attacks of inAamatory disorders of the most violent kind. Such injuries which in others would be unimpOrtant, produce in them severe in hamation, the nature of which is always Obsti- nate and in it's termination frequently fatal. They live in fact on the brink of disease the slightest accident often carries them off, and if they escape casualties, their habits of living lead to a variety of diseases and premature dissolution; the majority not surviving the age of fifty.-Med. Hut.

From the National Mtelligencer.

 GREECE.
full articles.article:
ANOTHER LETTER FROM DIR. HOWE. NAPoLI DI ROMAN, Sept. 12, 1926. Dear Sir; Since the date of my last, (Aug. 16) affairs have remained in nearly the same state as then described them to you, with this difference, however, that every day that the enemy is delayed from important operations, is day gained by the Greeks for it brings us nearer the rainy season, when they must necessarily give up, in great measure, hostile pro- ceedings.

 Athens has been closly invested for some time by the Albanians, under Reshed Pa- sha. In fact, he has possession of the lower town: for, the Greeks, finding it al- mostimpossible to defend the extensive cir cult of the walls, abandoned them and re- tired into the Acropolis, and body of Turks entered the place. On the 18th August,i it was resolved that an attack should be made upon them by the Greeks, who were without the town. Accordingly the Regulars, under Col. Fabvier, amounting 1 to about fifteen hundred men, and the Ir- regulars, under Canascakis, to three thou sand fell upon them, and drove them back some miles from the town, and cut them

 

 place. In this affair, the corps of Phil hellenians, composed of about 15O Euro peans, behaved in such manner as to force the admiration of Turks and Greeks. The next day, the enimy advanced again, and on the 2Oth they were again attacked and driven back. The affair lasted all day, and at dark it was arranged that the irreg- ulars should continue the pursuit, while the tactics Irregular troops] should remain in some gardens, a few miles from Athens as a Corps de rCserve. But what was the as- tonishment of Fabvier and his men, two hours after dark, when they thought the Greeks to be far in advance, to find the Turks, in vast numbers, rushing into the garden, sabre in hand, with their horrible cry of Allah-hu, and cutting bown all who opposed them. Confusion immediately succeeded.-Abattis, commander of the first battalion, either from weakness or misunderstanding, disobeyed his orders. and all retired rapidly to neighboring hill, from whence they endeavored with their four field pieces. to check the ene- my. Two of them breaking down they were obliged to leave them in the hands of the enemy, and continued their retreat to the shore opposite Salamis, where, after burying their cannon, they embarked, and crossed over to the Island, having lost a. bout 80 mon. Fabvier accused Canasca- kis of having betrayed him, but it will prob- ably turn out misunderstanding and, so far from being discouraged, the Greeks are prepairing to unite again and attack the en- imy. As for the Acropolis, the Turks cannot take it by assault: as for famine the garrison have provision for two years. Bombardment has been tried in vain, so that there remains no other way but that of mining This fear, in some measure 1; for, from tho almost perpendicular rising of the rock, on which the fortress is built, an enemy, who has possession of the town, may commence his operations almost under the feet of the besiegers; However, it would be exhibiting degree of skill and enter prise which have rarely shown in Turkish Armies,to attempt so tedious process.

 Ibrahim Pasha, greatly weakened and in want of endorsements, can undertake no operation more important than that ol burning villages, until the arrival of the Egyptian fleet, and this, it appears, ixde-

full articles.headline: A YEAR IN HUNGARY.
full articles.article:
A Tale, founded on fact, and translated from

 the Spanish of the Rev. Joseph Blanco

 White.

 triau service, took me with him, when only six years old, to Malines. The Archbishop of that city, the Count of F-, seeing me there at different times, took fancy to me, and offered to send me to Vienna, to be edu- cated in the house of his sister, the'C Countess of S--. until there should be vacancy

of silent love, which never would have bro ken from the secrecy of the heart to which it was confined, but for the evil fortune which cherished my fancy for a while with the de- ceitful delights of hope, in order to give d sharper edge to the suficrings that awaited both myself and the innocent object of my passion. While l resided with the two sis ters, the youthful gaiety and merriment with which they treated me, made me sort of voluntary slave to them both. One day when theIr father came to see us, he found me at 1 short distance from the house, drawing map 0t the surrounding country, from which af forwards formed the model now before you. was seated upon the grass beneath tree, but without my shoes upon my feet. "How IS this, my friend ," said he, ''are you so ecO- nomlcal as to wear your shoes only in the city 7" No sir" replied. ''my shoes are Tn your daug ghters' possession: for they lay an embargo on them whenever they wish to prevent my leaving the place." Upon hear ing this, the good man was ready to die with laughter; then, wishing to ascertain the na- ture of the employment in which he found me engaged, he began to examne the map. Such however was his ignorance, that he was ut terly incapable of comprehending the mean ing ot 1t. At length, after many efforts, Isuc- ceeded in making him perceive in it his own house, with the lake, the mountains, and the woods. He was perfectly astonished, and al most took me for magician.

 The situation in which now found my self, though delightful beyond measure, could ] not, was aware, continue much longer with 1 out producing crisis that must make me ei- ther happy or miserable for the remainder of my life.

 The time at length arrived when it became absolutely necessary for me to take my de- parture, and without having made, even indi- rectly, the slightest intmation of my passion to her who was the object of it. Overwhel- med in the melancholy of my thoughts, lost all my former animation and gaiety of spirits, which were succeeded by q dejection that in creased every hour. Instead of proposing as usual to accompany tho sisters in their walks and diversions, would retire. almost uncon- scious of what was doing, to the shade of tree, with some paper and pencil, as if for the purpose of drawing. There would sit for hours, and find at last that had not drawn line.

 One morning when wrapped up in one of these melancholy moods suddenly pcrcei- ved the two sisters. approaching slowly thro' the wood in which they found me. They advanced at a little distance from each other the younger appearing to lead the way; the object of my passion cast d look towards me, and then with blush retired behind her sis ter. But the younger, with countenance full ofl life and animation, opposed her retreat and taking her again by the hand, pulled her towards me speaking to her at the same time a few words, which l could not hear, in a tone of attectionate anger. She came up to l me at last, and with her accustomed iveliness said to me, You must tell us the cause of your melancholy, or we will instantly deprive you of the honor Ofbeng our knight-errant." Forcing a smile to my lip, endeavored to answer her in the same lively tone, but my ] tongue failed to execute nay wish: could only utter complaint against my ill-fortune in being under the necessity of taking my de- parture in few days. "Then you think of leaving us," continued the younger sister, Heaven knows," replied, "how deeply the thought of being obliged to do so affects me-" "And do you grieve for both of us C. quaIly?" The blush which instantly covered the face and neck of my beloved, blinded me at once to every other consideration, and, seizing her hand with transport. pressed it to nay lips-then dropped it moment to clasp within both of mine that of my kind medria tix. "Very well, sir" she replied, in a tone of affected gravity: !" l see plainly how little you care for me. Nevertheless, as I am of generous temper, and feel no desire for re- venge, shall now inform thee, most sorrow full knight, that have put the question for thee to my sister, and that thou hast only to get the rank of captain forthwith, in order to be sure of obtaining the incOmparable happi- ness and exalted honour, &c. Sc. of being her husband.-Bless the man he stands as if he had been turned into statuc."

 l Such indeedI renamed fora few moments: then in a transport exclaimed, " Is it possible? Surely you are deceiying me. .'-"No, no,my friend, she does not deceive you," replied my beloved: and throwing her arms around her sisters neck, bathed her cheek with grateful tears.

 Happy! thrice happy am l." exclaim- ed: the rank which you have made the condi- ton of our marriage,will be obtained in a few days. We shall part, therefore. since my pro- fessional duty requires it; but soon shall you behold me here again, to claim the promised hand of her whom adore"

 (To be concluded in our nert.)

 Free Living.-One of the most common causes of all violent disorders, is that which is popularly termed fullness of the vessels, or technically, plethoric condition of the sys- tenn, arising from errors in diet; from excess or imprudent indulgence in the quality or

Vienna, where was brought up with the ne- phew of the Archbishop; who, together with his relations, all persons of great influence, | showed me the strongest marks of affection, and promoted to the utmost my education at the academy.

 At the time when held only the rank of a lieutenant, l was selected by the government ! for the purpose of making some trigOnOmetri- cal surveys in Hungary. l set out according ly, with an escort of soldiers appointed for the management of the mathematical instruments. On the road l found myself treated like a prince by all the post masters, who, at the very sound of the name of an officer cOmmis- stoned by the court. will almost lick the ground to serve him. NOrecOmmendatiOn,h however, of this kind is required to induce the upper classes to give an officer frank and hospita- ble reception. The hospitality, indeed, which | reigns through Hungary, together with the primitive simplicity and purity of manners, which at the period speak of prevailed a. mong the females of the country, will very plainly appearin the course of my narrative. Being young, soldier, and employed by the government, could scarcely fail of hay ing much attention paid to me at Presburg.- had not been long there before the season of Carnival came on: during which the no- bles are in the habit of giving public balls.- The customs of the country on this occasion are singular. Should there be garrison, or any officers in the city, they immediately re- ceive tickets of admission to the balls, without being at any trouble to procure them. The directors make a list of all who are invited ;- and if the number of men should be found to exceed that of females, they propose the names of some young ladies of their acquan- tance, which are inserted in the list to make up the deficiency. When this is done, it would be considered improper in the parents ofthe young ladies to prevent their daughters from attending the balls.

 "As soon as they commenced, I became acquainted with two sisters, the ladies of P-, young women of great beauty and agreeable manners: the elder excelled in the waltz, the younger loved the country dance. was charmed with them both but soon from day to day. Yet why should I cherish or make known passion which could not terminate happily? What folly, for a young

 lieutenant without fortune, to think of offering his hand to young female, born :o higher and better hopes On the last day, however, of our meeting, l could do no less, as l had no acquaintance with the family of my partner, than take my leave. by saying to her, We have now danced the keruhW tor concusion) and in truth here my story ends, for shall never see you again." "Not so,'' she repli- ed, with an openness of manner quite idnes- cribable," unless indeed you wish to run away from us. Every thing is arranged for your visiting in our family. My father knows who you are; and |, too, am more interested in the matter than, perhaps, you imagine.- Come, therefore, if you please, and visit us to- morrow" Such innocence and simplicity won possession in moment of my whole heart; though to say the truth, the whole of it had been made captive long before. re- solved, however, at the same time most firm Iy not to abuse in the slightest degree the O. penness and simplicity of the fair object of my love.

 Hitherto my residence had been in the I'm perial Castle; which, as it commands, both in a geographical and military se:se, the city and the Danube, affords to the eye one of the Ioveliest prospects to be met with in Hungary. From the moment, however, in which l re- ccived the invitation l have mentioned, till that of my departure with a beating heart to pay the expected visit, Presburg and the Danube with all their beauties, had vanished | from my eyes. Scarcely upon my arrival at their fathers, had entered the house, when the two sisters, placing themselves one on each side of me, took me by the hand to in troduce me to him. In spite of the agitation ofmy mind, could scarcely forbear smiling when the good knight received me as if he had been bishop pronouncing blessing over me.

 Uprl my asking the reason of so unusual a ceremony, l immediately perceived by the answer given to me, the state of ignorance and superstition in which the country was sunk; for the object in making the sign of the cross over me was, they said, to prevent my entrance into their house from being attended with any iIl-fortune. Would that such a precaution could have been efectual! or that, in the room of superstitious ceremony, l could have offered prayer to Heaven capa- ble of averting the misfortunes which l was the innocent means of bringing upon the fam fly who had so hospitably received me under their roof.

 Ihad continued for some time 10 visit them with the freedom of "a near relation, when one day their father said to me, My friend, have favour to ask of you. My wife is so unwel that am prevented from going to my estate in the country, as had at first intend ed. But, as my daughters know how to man. age my affairs there as well as myself, 1 think of sending them thither in my place, and should be greatly obliged to you, if you would accompany them." Such a request | f oc c%I

A Coop HIT.-ScasOnGbL for Con- greSS.-Mr. Sergeant POpham, when Speaker of the House of Commons, which had sat long and done nothing, coming one day to Queen Elizabeth, she said to him, Now MT. Speaker, what has pas 1 sed'in the House?" He answered, "May it please your Majesty-eIcUem weeks F''- FIREs.-The extensive Iron Works at Carthage, N. Y. where destroyed by fire on the night of 22d ut. They were in- sured.-On the 30th ut. three story wooden house, corner of Prince and Cros- by streets, New ork, was mostly con- sumed. The Presbyterian Church in Murray street narrowly escaped confa- grafton on the following evening, fire hav- ing communicated from one of the fues used to warm it.-A fire broke out in Northampton, in a room occupied by MT. Colton, as Looking-glass factory; it was extinguished with little damage.

 A certain doctor Fitch gives in the Ga zette, paper published at Le Roy, Gen. nessee County, N. Y. that he will take produce in payment for his physic,i if deliv- cred at his barn by the 10th inst; and from those who are poor and cannot pay mon- ey or produce, he will take Brush fence or Buck Vheat Straw, if they will only bring it by that time.

 GEORGIA LEG1sLATURE.-A bill has passed the House of Represetatives, ap- propriating 10000 dollars for the purpose of clearing and deepning the River Savan- nah, between Augusta and Savannah.- The work is to be executed under the superintendence of four commissioners, and in conjunction with the state of South Carolina, as proposed by that State on previous occasions.

1UHtOGt0IUtOfC uN LlACCHCOIS Dl,UU Commissioner S1,25 The following beautiful lines of original po- ctry were written in young ladies Album & thence transcribed for this paper.1 HOW COLD ARE THESE SKIES! How cold are these skies Hoary winter re-

 ciined

 On his snow drifts, the charms of earth's be-

 som defOrms And the fields and the groves and the heavens

 are signed To the rule and the wrath of the spirits of

 storms.

 Yet these cold skies the earth have drest| In saint-like vesture, white and warm; And spread mantle OCT her breast, To shield it from the freezing storm. So not the coldest blast, that flies Ger hOpe's young flowers, the heart shall

 chill,

 If in the storm, it Iowiy lies And waits the AlI-ruling Spirits will.

 J.P. I4itchheld, Jan. II, 1897. The following lines were written by the Hon. Henry St. George Tucker, of Virginia, on being requested to know why he had ceas- ed to court the poetic muse. Days of my youth, ye have gIided away, Hairs of my youth, ye are frosted and gray, Eyes ofmy youth, your keen sight is no more. Checks of my youth, ye are furrow'd all Der, Strength of my youth. all your vgour is gone, Thoughts of my youth, your gay visions are

 flown.

 Days Of my youth, wish not your recall, Hairs of my youth, I'm content ye should fall, Eyes of my youth, ye much evil have seen, Cheeks of my youth, bath < in tears ye have

 been,

 Thoughts of my youth, ye have led me astray, Strength of my youth why lament your de-

 cay.

 Days of my age. ye will shortly he past, Pains of my age, yet awhile ye can last, Joys ofmy age, in true wisdom delight, Eyes of my age, be Religion your light, Thoughts of my age, dread ye not the cold

 sod,

 Hopes of my age be ye fix'd on your God. These beautiful lines are from the Memori- dl. published in Boston by True and Green "Cornelia," Mrs. Hale, is called by some of the Buston papers, "and not inaptly' (says the Atbion) the Mrs. Hemans of America.

 THE LIGHT OF HOME.

 

 And thy spirit will sigh to roam, And thou must go ;-but never when there, Forget the light of home. Though pleasure may smile with ray more

 bright,

 It dazzles to lead astray; Like the meteor's flash twill deepen the night, When thou treadest thy lo:.ely way. But the hearth of home has constant flame, And pure as vestal fire; Twill burn, twill burn forever the same, For nature feeds the pyre. The sea of ambition is tempcst-tost, And thy hopes may vanish like foam But when sa,s are shiver'd and rudder lost Then look to the light of home. And there like star through the midnight

 cloud

 Thou shalt see the beacon bright, For never, till shining on thy shroud, Can be quenched its holy light. The sun of fame, aye twill gid the name, But the heart ne'er felt its ray; And fashions smiles that rich ones claim, Are but beams of wintry day. And how cold and how dim those beams

 would be,

 Should life's wretched wanderer come And my hoy. when the world is dark to thee. Then turn to the light of home.

 CORNELIA.

 A YEAR IN HUNGARY. A Tale, founded on fact, and translated from the Spanish of the Rev. Joseph Blanco White.

 "My father, who was Major in the Aus trian service, took me with him, when only six years old, to Malines. The Archbishop of that city, the Count of -, seeing me there at different times, took fancy to me, and offered to send me to Vienna, to be edu-

full articles.headline: From the Trenton Emporium. THE MEMORY OF FRIENDSHIP.
full articles.article:
THE MEMORY OF FRIENDSHIP. Amid the deepest shades of gloom,

 That brood OCT life's decline, A vision rises from the tomb

 Lost friendship it is thine !- Thou comest like pilgrim grey. But light is round thy misty way,

 The light of early love When life was fresh and hope was high, And rainbows spahn'd the cloudless sky, And music filled the grove. 1t was joyous season. Mirth

 Fill'd up the laughing hours o then we never thought that earth

 Could nourish aught but flowers ARd oft when, in the still profound, We gaz'd upon the mountains round,

 Or trod the valley green Or mingled in the giddy rout, Till the far rocks sent back the shout,

 We deem that life had been, From ages past, a fairy dream

 OfunalIoy'd delight Der which young joys meridian beam

 Each day threw rays more bright. 1t was the summers calm-the bloom That clothes the flowers ere tempests come; The pause-when far and still, The cradled storm is lulPd to rest, And on the verdant valleys breast

 The dews their balm distil Once-'twas day as beautiful

 As ever knew the eastern cline, When flowers invited maids to cuI

 Them in their glorious prime l cast long ing, lingering look On the still vale and winding brook,

 And saw the laughing band Of merry school-mates gathering To the accustom'd sportive ring

 All sniling-hand in hand. My heart was light even then-I left

 My boyhOod's pleasant dome Nor knew till far, of friends bereft,

 How dear is home-sweet home But it was pleasant still, in dreams, To visit my own native streams-

 To join the good and gay To think how from the worlds rude blast should escape, and fly at last

 To home--to frienGs---for aye, Life had its troubles-I was worn

 With pain aud toll and care; MislOrtunes came-hut they were borne, And hope repelld dspar- At length the chain was broken-and sought once more my native land--

 My own sweet valley rangd- Its meads and brooks were still the same Twas to my home-my home-I came,

 But oh that home had chang'd! That gladsome band was scatter'd-gone-

 Over the worlds wide waste trimm'd our household fire alone, #

 The church yard had the rest stood upon the school-house green The place deserted long had been

 And, as weary pilgrim wends, He knows not whither-day by day, rov'd a-down life's dreary way,

 My all the memory of friends. -I D.

!Sheridan's Greek.-Lord Be!grave having clenched a speech in the House of Commons with Greek quotation, Sheridan, in reply, admitted the force of the quotation as far as it went, "but'' said he "had the Noble Lord proceeded little farther, and completed the passage, he would have seen that it applied the other way" Sheridan then spouted something, ore rOtundo, which had all the ais, ous, kon, and kous, that give the world assu- rance of Greek quotation; upon which Lord BeIgrave very promptly and handsome ly compimented the Hon. Member on his readiness of recollection, and frankly admit ted that the continuation of the passage had the tendency ascribed to it by Sheridan, and that he had overlooked it at the moment when he gave his quotation. On the break ing up of the House, Fox, piqued himself on having some Greek, went up to Sheridan and asked him, Sheridan, how came you to be so ready with. that passage it certainly is as you say, but was not aware of it before you quoted it." It is unnecessary to observe, that there was no Greek Gt QU in Sheridan's inn promptu!

 Panthers killed.-A Monticello, N. Y. date of 29th Dec. says:

 "TwO Partners, one measuring nine feet from the nose to the tip of the tail, the other smaller. were killed a short time since in the town of Bethel, about seven miles from this village, by MT. Nelson Crocker. They were two out of drove of nine, probably emigrating from our woods to a warmer eli mate. One of the remaining seven was bad ly wounded, but not so much so as to be ta- ken. Our hunters have pursued them, and will give good account of them.

full articles.article:
The following lines were written by the Hon. Henry St. George Tucker, of Virginia, on being requested to know why he had ceas- ed to court the poetic muse. Days of my youth, ye have gIided away, Hairs of my youth, ye are frosted and gray, Eyes ofmy youth, your keen sight is no more, Checks of my youth, ye are furrow'd all OCT, Strength of my youth. all your vgour is gone, Thoughts of my youth, your gay visions are

 flown.

Free Living.-One of the most common causes of all violent disorders, is that which is popularly termed fullness of the vessels, or technically, plethoric condition of the sys- tenn, arising from errors in diet; from excess or imprudent indulgence in the quality or quantity of food and drink The indulgences produce and keep up an unnatural excitement,

 under whick accidental circumstances now

 readily occasion disease of an acute and infia-

 matory character. They also affect the or gans of digestion, which arc possessed of all

 most unive ersal sympathy, and by furnishing an excessive quantity of new supplies, over load the vascular system, bringing it into a

 state in which local disease may be very easi-

 ly produced; and instead of furnishing healthy

 nourishment, convey the seeds of disease over the whole body. Individuals are not aware of the tendency of the habits in which they daily indulge, until disease manifests itself in 1 various parts of the body. In the first instance too pIethoric condition is eVinced by in crease is bulk, and Aorid, or rather healthy appearance but if we investigate the matter l more closely. we shall find that such persons
